awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: RAPID: Empowering Math Teachers with an AI Tool for Auto-Generation of Technology-Enhanced Assessments
awd_abstract_narration:
The proliferation of artificial intelligence (AI) and powerful Large Language Models (LLMs) has evoked excitement and confusion among K-12 teachers regarding AI's impact on teaching, assessments, and student work. It is vital for researchers with expertise in human-centered teaching and learning to share empirically grounded proofs-of-concept of teacher-AI teaming to enhance teacher capacities for better learning outcomes for all students. This RAPID project examines how the use of LLM-powered tools in high school math classes empowers teachers to create complex technology-enhanced assessments (TEAs) that formatively measure higher-order thinking skills and facilitate deeper learning. The task of authoring such TEAs has necessitated programming expertise and extensive technical skills and thus excluded most K-12 math teachers from participating. By showcasing an exemplary model of teacher-AI teaming, this project addresses a crucial, timely need to establish an early, positive narrative that places teachers at the center of the AI revolution in K-12 education. This proposal was received in response to the Dear Colleague Letter (DCL): Rapidly Accelerating Research on Artificial Intelligence in K-12 Education in Formal and Informal Settings (NSF 23-097) and funded by the Innovative Technology Experiences for Students and Teachers (ITEST) program, which supports projects that build understandings of practices, program elements, contexts and processes contributing to increasing students' knowledge and interest in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) and information and communication technology (ICT) careers.

This time-sensitive project will advance research on the use of AI and LLMs for teaching in high school mathematics classrooms through the use of Edfinity software that uses the open-source WeBWorK format to generate interactive, auto-gradable, technology-enhanced formative assessments to support student learning. Within this context, teachers will describe a math problem with an LLM tool (ALICE) that is trained to use natural language inputs, generating source code for TEAs along with hints and student feedback. The project brings together a multidisciplinary team of math educators, STEM education and learning sciences researchers, K-12 teacher educators, AI tool developers, and AI experts to examine the integration of ALICE into high school Finite Mathematics courses across 34 rural, urban, and suburban schools in Indiana and Illinois. The project will train high school teachers and gather data to advance and shape our understanding of teacher-AI teaming and domain-specific LLM prompt engineering. The research involves gathering log data from the platform on teachers' ALICE usage and prompt engineering, as well as teacher feedback through surveys and interviews. These data will be analyzed to understand teachers' experiences in using an LLM tool, the impacts on teacher attitudes toward and confidence in AI, and the success of ALICE from teachers' perspectives for the generation of quality, interactive, formative assessments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The ‘Empowering Math Teachers with an AI Tool for Auto-Generation of Technology-Enhanced Assessments’ (TEAMAI) project was a collaboration between the Indiana University math department and ‘Looking Glass Ventures’ whose popular homework system/assessment platform, Edfinity.com, was created through prior NSF SBIR grants. Edfinity meets the growing demand for formative technology-enhanced assessments (TEAs) with interactive approaches that promote equity, measure higher-order thinking skills, and facilitate deeper learning. Complex TEAs use the open-source WeBWorK format that requires programming at the back-end. ALICE, Edfinity’s Generative AI (GenAI) model has been trained to take as input a natural language prompt and generate WeBWorK source code that would otherwise have to be laboriously written by programmers or teachers with coding expertise. ALICE thus democratizes TEA authoring as a no-code solution for all teachers. The project was situated in the context of IU’s Advanced College Project (ACP) dual-enrollment program which engages schools in Indiana and Illinois. This RAPID project presented a timely opportunity to examine highschool teachers’ use of GenAI tools as IU adopted Edfinity for multiple courses including Finite Math and Calculus I, and wanted to provide their ACP math teachers with an opportunity to use Edfinity and ALICE in their courses prior to broader adoption.

Inspired by, and aligned with, national efforts to understand the use and role of AI in K-12 education, TEAMAI's goals were to augment teacher capabilities and empower them to author TEAs for their classroom context; foster AI literacy and trust among teachers; and contribute to the understanding of successful teacher-GenAI teaming through research conducted by an interdisciplinary team involving math educators, learning scientists, and AI researchers. To this end, in AY 2023-2024, we conducted a year-long research to examine highschool Math teachers’ experiences as they partner with ALICE to generate TEAs and what factors influenced these experiences as well as teachers’ views on prompt engineering and AI, and how they were impacted by this experience.


Teachers from rural, urban, and suburban highschools in Indiana and Illinois were recruited at the start of each semester. Our data sources included (a) Individual teacher logs with reflections on their satisfaction with, and feedback on, the prompt and the problem generated, use with students, and re-submission with tweaks; (b) Pre-post teacher surveys with responses to their views on AI and the ALICE experience; (c) semi-structured interviews with teachers who opted in for the interview; and (d) a corpus of over 400 teachers’ prompts and math problems generated for topics in Finite Mathematics, Brief Survey of Calculus I, and Calculus 1.


Teachers’ experiences with ALICE in both semesters were mostly very positive. In the post-survey, almost all teachers responded “4” (agree) or “5” (completely agree) to “I have enjoyed this experience of using ALICE to generate questions for use in my course.”, “Working with ALICE helped me with generating creative word problems.”, “This experience has made me aware of uses of AI that I had not thought of before.”, and to “Uses of generative AI like ALICE have the potential to positively impact classroom teaching.” Themes that emerged from teachers' responses to their description of their ALICE experience included: enhanced efficiency, ease of Implementation, teacher empowerment, learning curve with respect to prompt engineering, and teachers’ attitude toward AI. A qualitative analysis of teacher interviews at the end of school year revealed that teachers’ overall experience with GenAI was influenced by: 

– Context of use

– Usefulness in teaching,

– Prompt creation and refinement process,

– Student use & reactions,

– Whether they viewed AI as a thought partner,

– Comparison with usual approach to assessments, and 

– Attitude toward AI in education.


Although participating teachers’ experiences varied, the results of this study are very promising. Findings suggest that it was not only a very positive experience for over 85% of the teachers but it also opened their eyes to the possibilities of use of AI. They found value in being able to generate practice problems, especially on topics on which they felt students needed help. Having isomorphic TEAs meant they could produce multiple practice problems for their students. This experience with ALICE aided their teaching and alleviated their assessment creation-related burden without requiring them to change how they normally taught. Prompt engineering presented an interesting challenge and learning curve for teachers. Prompts and problems created in this research are also useful products for future use. Our results have been shared through a published paper and multiple conference presentations in the US and abroad.

 

This project examined how teachers partner with GenAI in a technical and high-need subject such as highschool math that is foundational for STEM in college and building the next-generation STEM workforce. Our findings have implications for a future of AI in education as we develop a deeper understanding of ways to help teachers partner effectively with AI to support their teaching.
